awd_titl_txt: NRI: EAGER: Teaching Aerial Robots to Perch Like a Bat via AI-Guided Design and Control
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will develop the scientific and technological foundations for design of small unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) with bat shapes and flying abilities. These bat-like UAVs will be non-intrusive and safe to operate in shared spaces to provide situational awareness to humans. Our bat-inspired design will also be collision-tolerant to negotiate cluttered, hard-to-access environments in the physical world. The resulting technology can significantly improve public safety and vehicular dynamic traffic control in smart cities and cost-effectiveness associated with monitoring environmental disasters. Ultimately, the UAV can provide computing, communication and sensing capabilities in large-scale systems such as, residential buildings, streets, construction zones, and state parks. These capabilities should result in enormous societal impact and economic benefit. In addition, as the result of this project, a new generation of scientists and engineers will be trained in addressing multidisciplinary challenges at the intersection of theory and experiment. The project will create programs and tools to train workforce with new skills including bio-inspired robotics, machine learning and artificial intelligence, and nonlinear control theory. 

This research adopts an artificial intelligence-guided framework to study bat's flight maneuvers including perching (i.e. upside-down landing), zero-path flight, and hovering. Due to the fact that the salient aspects of the bat's wing motion can be represented in a low-dimensional subspace, we will apply an auto-encoding variational inference approach on the flying data from real animal  in order to extract low dimensional, yet interpretable, embedding of the its underlying flight model. We will also use a high-fidelity virtual environment for 3D modeling, synthetic design and validation of the extracted low-dimensional latent variables. This will also lead to better understating of the bat sensory feedback mechanism through a data-driven procedure. Our research objective will simplify the engineering procedure to design bio-inspired aerial co-robots that closely mimic the flight behavior of a target animal, therefore is directly towards lowering the barriers for understanding fundamentals regarding closed-loop control and design of bio-inspired multimodal co-robots. In order to achieve the proposed research objectives, we will center our effort around conducting two main phases during the one year timeline of this project: first, AI-guided analysis and modeling of bat's various flight maneuvers, and second, development of a soft and collision-tolerant bat-inspired aerial agent capable of landing on structures. These two phases will be accomplished by team's cross-disciplinary collaborative, as components are highly interlinked and dependent.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit outcome

In this period, we achieved the following milestones towards materializing the project's main objective, which is learning how to land like a bat.

1- We developed a comprehensive flight dynamics model of the articulated flapping flight during a heel-above-the-head maneuver. Our model employs a mathematical description of the fluid-structure interactions in our flapping robot based on horseshoe vortex models and Wagner functions. 

2- We accomplished an experimental verification of the Wagner model in this period. The model realistically describes six axes force-moment at CG during the land maneuver. 

3- We proposed, designed, and tested a control design framework based on integrated mechanical intelligence, and control. The proposed model relaxes the curse of dimensionality in articulated flapping flight by i) designing computational structures and ii) optimal placement of actuators within the computational structures. 

Achieving this milestone facilitated a hardware design that constitutes the backbone for our future tests and experimentations. We experimentally validated a hardware design based on the proposed robot control framework (briefly explained above). The tests support the idea that computational structures can be used to accommodate dynamic morphing in flapping-wing flights.

The result of our work in this phase culminated in a robotdemonstration, which can be seen here: https://youtu.be/23qLrvm23-E?list=TLGGOifPbAKbASowMTExMjAyMQ

Although we did not demonstrate the landing maneuver with our robot yet, our preliminary experimental results support our approach to achieving dynamic morphing based on computational structures and closed-loop feedback. Dynamic morphing is key to bats heel-above-the-head maneuvers, and as a result, we have been close to reaching our overarching objective, copying bat's landing maneuvers.

Broader impact outcome

1- We trained a post-doctoral researcher (Dr. Eric Sihite) as part of the funding. Currently, Dr. Sihite, with the help of several publications led by this research, secured another post-doctoral research position at Caltech's Division For Engineering and Science.

2- Besides, we trained two Ph.D. students (Akshath Singhal and Paul Ghanem). Both PhD students made their first paper submissions to top-tier robotic conferences as the result of this funding.

3- The undergraduate students Madeline Weaver and Matt Schroeter spent their summer programming the robot and designing robotic wings. Matt Schroeter received NU's PEAK AWARD based on the research results as part of the NSF program.

4- We published our results in top-tier robotics conferences, including IROS, ICRA, ACC, CDC, GNC, and AIM. We are submitting a journal paper concluding our results obtained in this program. 


Last Modified: 11/01/2021
Modified by: Alireza Ramezani
